{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox event | title = Ughill Hall shootings | image = File:Ughill Hall (geograph 4425431) (cropped).jpg | image_upright = | image_alt = | caption = [[Ughill Hall]] in 2015 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | english_name = | time = | duration = | date = {{start date|df=yes|1986|09|21}} | venue = | location = Ughill Hall, [[Sheffield]], United Kingdom | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | also_known_as = | type = | theme = | cause = | motive = | target = | first_reporter = | budget = | patron = <!-- or |patrons= --> | organisers = <!-- or |organizers= --> | filmed_by = | participants = | outcome = | casualties1 = | casualties2 = | casualties3 = | reported deaths = 2 | reported injuries = 1 | reported missing = | reported property damage = | burial = | inquiries = | inquest = | coroner = | arrests = | suspects = | accused = | convicted = Ian Wood | charges = [[Murder in English law|Murder]] (×2), [[attempted murder]], [[theft]] | trial = | verdict = Guilty | convictions = | sentence = Two [[Life imprisonment|life sentences]] plus 15 years | publication_bans = | litigation = | awards = | url = | blank_label = Ian Wood | blank1_label = <!-- or |blank1_data= --> | blank2_label = <!-- or |blank2_data= --> | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | notes = }} On 21 September 1986, Ian Wood shot and killed his [[mistress (lover)|mistress]] Danielle Ledez and her daughter Stephanie (aged 3) and severely injured Christopher (aged 5), Ledez's elder child, at [[Ughill#Ughill Hall|Ughill Hall]] in [[Bradfield, South Yorkshire|Bradfield]] near [[Sheffield]], United Kingdom. Wood left his [[Enfield No. 2|.38 Enfield revolver]] in the kitchen and called the police before fleeing the scene. He went on the run for over a week, making several telephone calls to journalists and family members. Eight days later he threatened to [[Jumper (person)|jump off]] the [[Amiens Cathedral]] in France but was talked down by the police after seven hours. He was then extradited back to Sheffield for trial.
On 30 July 1987, Wood was convicted on two counts of murder, one of attempted murder and one of theft, after a week-long trial. He had pleaded not guilty to the murder of Danielle, instead submitting a manslaughter plea claiming he killed her to complete a [[suicide pact]]. An appeal against the guilty verdict was filed a month later and rejected in 1989. The case impacted upon [[Firearms policy in the United Kingdom|British firearms policy]], especially the manner in which regional police forces communicate over firearm ownership.
==Background== Ian Wood (born 1949) began renting Ughill Hall, an 18-room mansion on the outskirts of Bradfield, with his mistress Danielle Ledez in April 1986 after leaving his wife Margaret and his three children.<ref name="24sep86-guardian-1" /> Wood was a solicitor and the ex secretary of the [[Law Society]] in Sheffield.<ref name="23sep86-times-1" /><ref name="vaw">{{cite book|last1=Hanmer|first1=Jalna|last2=Saunders|first2=Sheila|title=Women, violence and crime prevention: a West Yorkshire study|date=1993|page=43|publisher=Avery|isbn=9781856282376}}</ref>
Danielle Ledez (1948-1986) was a French teacher from [[Amiens]], France, who moved to Ughill Hall with Wood and her two children whilst in the process of divorcing her second husband (and father of the children) Colin Lloyd, a teacher from Sheffield.<ref name="24sep86-guardian-1" /><ref name="glasgowherald-25sep86-1">{{cite news|title=Churchman in plea to missing solicitor|work=The Glasgow Herald|date=25 September 1986}}</ref>
==Shootings== [[File:Flingues-p1030067.jpg|thumb|An [[Enfield No. 2]] revolver similar to the one Wood used.]] At approximately 12 midnight on 21 September 1986, Wood went to the playroom in the mansion and killed his mistress Danielle Ledez by shooting her once in the head.<ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /><ref name="scotlawjournal">{{cite book|title=The Journal of the Law Society of Scotland|date=1987|publisher=The Society|page=249}}</ref> Ledez was 10 weeks pregnant by Wood.<ref name="26sep86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Fugitive talks to journalist |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503073269&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 26 September 1986}}</ref><ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /> Wood then proceeded to play [[hide-and-seek]] with Ledez's daughter Stephanie (aged 3), after which he led her into Christopher's bedroom and shot her twice in the head, killing her instantly.<ref name="23jul87-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor said his mistress 'urged him to murder her' |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF500493761&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |last=Smith|first=Ian|page=5|subscription=yes|work=The Times|date=23 July 1987}}</ref><ref name="22jul87-indy-1">{{cite news|title=Solicitor 'agreed suicide pact'|work=The Independent|date=22 July 1987}}</ref> He then took Ledez's son Christopher (aged 5) into the bathroom and told him to close his eyes as he had a surprise for him, then shot him twice in the head. Wood then bludgeoned the boy with a large ruler four or five times in the back of the head.<ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /><ref name="22jul87-times-1">{{cite news|title=Solicitor killed his mistress 'as part of a suicide pact'|url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF501722001&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0|last=Smith|first=Ian|page=3|subscription=yes|work=The Times|date=22 July 1987}}</ref>
Wood changed clothes, packed his bags, and left the house shortly afterwards, leaving the weapon he used, an [[Enfield No. 2|.38 Enfield revolver]], in the kitchen with one live round left.<ref>{{Cite news |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260311560/ |title= 'Respectable' solicitor whose life was a tangled web of deceit |page=2 |via= Newspapers.com |subscription=yes |date= 31 July 1987 |work= The Guardian|access-date= |archive-url= |archive-date= |deadurl=}}</ref><ref name="23jul87-times-1" /> The police went to the mansion on the evening of 22 September 1986 after receiving a telephone call from Wood; finding all the doors and windows locked, they broke down the door.<ref name="23sep86-times-1" /> Christopher was rushed to [[Sheffield Children's Hospital]] with severe head injuries and was placed on life support after surviving without medical attention for 21 hours.<ref name="24sep86-times-1" /><ref name="23jul87-indy-1">{{cite news|title=Boy shot by solicitor lay hurt for 21 hours|work=The Independent|date=23 July 1987}}</ref>
==Manhunt== ===Initial response=== Following the discovery of the bodies, the police appealed to Wood to turn himself in and warned members of the public not to approach him as he may be armed.<ref name="23sep86-guardian-1">{{cite news |title= Ian Wood wanted for Ledez murders |last=Perera |first=Shyama |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260269379|page=1|via= Newspapers.com |subscription=yes |work= The Guardian |date= 23 September 1986}}</ref><ref name="23sep86-times-1">{{cite news |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503071822&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |title= Plea to solicitor after two gunshot deaths |last= Smith |first=Ian |page=1 |work= The Times |date=23 September 1986 |subscription= yes}}</ref> Wood's wife Margaret and their three children were put under police protection immediately, as was Ledez's husband Colin Lloyd.<ref name="23sep86-guardian-1" /> A total of five homes in England were put under protection throughout the manhunt.<ref name="25sep86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor sought by Interpol |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503072752&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |last=Smith |first=Ian |page=1 |subscription=yes |work= The Times |date= 25 September 1986}}</ref> A formal arrest warrant was issued on 23 September 1986 with more details on Wood's flight, including the numberplate of the car he fled in.<ref name="23sep86-guardian-1" /><ref name="24sep86-times-1">{{cite news |title=Warrant is issued for solicitor |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503072228&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=1 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 24 September 1986}}</ref>
===Phone calls=== On 23 September 1986, a police press conference was interrupted when Wood made a series of telephone calls to Brenda Tunney, a reporter for the local newspaper ''[[Sheffield Weekly Gazette]]''.<ref name="bufvc">{{cite web|last1=Allerenshaw|first1=Bill|last2=Tunney|first2=Brenda|date=31 July 1987|title=Ian Wood begins murder sentence|url=http://bufvc.ac.uk/tvandradio/lbc/index.php/segment/0009800174001|website=British Universities Film and Video Council}}</ref><ref name="24sep86-guardian-1">{{cite news|title=Ian Wood alleged to have shot his mistress and her children|work=The Guardian|date=24 September 1986}}</ref> Wood refused to disclose his location but claimed the purpose of the calls was to "put his side".<ref name="24sep86-guardian-1" />
Wood made no further telephone calls to either the police or journalists for nearly 48 hours after the initial series of calls.<ref name="26sep86-guardian-1">{{cite news|title=Solicitor breaks silence |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260270466/?terms=Solicitor%2Bbreaks%2Bsilence |last= Parkin |first=Michael |via= Newspapers.com |subscription= yes |page=2 |work= The Guardian |date= 26 September 1986}}</ref> By 26 September he had made at least eight phone calls.<ref name="28-sep-86-st1">{{cite news |title= New phone clue in murder hunt |work= The Sunday Times |date= 28 September 1986}}</ref> On 27 September, Wood called Tunney four times asking about funeral arrangements for Ledez and her daughter.<ref name="28-sep-86-st1" /> The police discussed the [[wikt:state of mind|mental state]] of Wood with a consultant psychiatrist on the same day due to the firearm confiscations and the phone calls.<ref name="27-sep-86-guard-1">{{cite news|title=Psychiatrist advises murder inquiry |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260270742/ |last= Parkin |first= Michael |via= Newspapers.com |subscription= yes |page=2 |work= The Guardian |date= 27 September 1986}}</ref> The following day, Wood made three more calls to Tunney and threatened suicide in one of them; he claimed he killed because of "love and desperation, not anger and hate".<ref name="29sept86-guardian-1">{{cite news |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260271020/ |title= I'll kill myself, says wanted solicitor |last=Keel |first= Paul |via= Newspapers.com |subscription= yes |page=1 |work= The Guardian |date= 29 September 1986}}</ref><ref name="mammoth" />
===Potential whereabouts=== On 25 September, a receptionist at the [[The Automobile Association|Automobile Association]] office in [[Barnstaple]] reported that a man matching Wood's description had requested an international driving licence.<ref name="26sep86-guardian-1" /> [[Interpol]] were notified of the case on the same day, after which French police interviewed Ledez's parents.<ref name="25sep86-times-1" /> Up until this point, Wood, who owned no other properties, was believed by police to still be in the [[Yorkshire]] area.<ref name="28-sep-86-st1" /> After Wood's capture, British and French authorities were "puzzled" by the ease with which Wood travelled under his own name.<ref name="30sep-86-guardian-1" /><ref name="1-oct-86-guardian-1" /> At his trial, it was established that Wood had gone to a pub after committing the killings and then, over the course of the next few days, travelled to [[Dover]] where he caught a ferry to France.<ref name="31jul87-indy-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor gets life as jury rejects suicide pact claim |work= The Independent |date= 31 July 1987}}</ref>
===Surrender=== [[File:Ian Wood on gargoyle 1986.png|thumb|Ian Wood on the gargoyle at Amiens Cathedral]] On 29 September, Wood joined a public tour of [[Amiens Cathedral]], approximately {{convert|3|mi}} away from Ledez's birthplace, but broke away from the tour group at about 12 noon, climbed over the parapet, and clung to a gargoyle about {{convert|200|ft}} above the ground, threatening to commit suicide by [[Jumper (person)|jumping off]].<ref name="mammoth">{{cite book|last1=Odell|first1=Robin|last2=Donnelley|first2=Paul|title=The Mammoth Book of More Bizarre Crimes|date=4 February 2016|publisher=Hachette UK|isbn=9781472118042|pages=212–213}}</ref><ref name="upi">{{cite news|title=Foreign News Briefs|work=United Press International|date=29 September 1986}}</ref><ref name="30-sep-86-times-1">{{cite news|title=Hunt for solicitor ends in Amiens|url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503074571&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0|work=The Times|last1=McCarthy|first1=Michael|last2=Geddes|first2=Diana|page=1|subscription=yes|date=30 September 1986}}</ref> He left a note with a member of staff at the cathedral shortly beforehand informing them of his intention to commit suicide, which prompted them to call the police.<ref name="30-sep-86-times-1" />
The police, firemen, the church's priest, and members from the British Consulate pleaded with Wood for seven hours, at which point Wood surrendered.<ref name="30-sep-86-times-1" /><ref name="30sep-86-guardian-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor gives in after 7 hours on cathedral |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260271321/ |last= Page |first= Campbell |via= Newspapers.com |pages=1, 36 |subscription= yes |work= The Guardian |date= 30 September 1986}}</ref> A crowd of several hundred people had gathered to watch from below.<ref name="30-sept-86-ap-1" /> Wood later claimed that he did not wish his family to see his fall on television, describing the scene as "a circus".<ref name="circus">{{cite news |title= Suicide bid 'just like a circus' |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503075011&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=1 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date=1 October 1986 }}</ref> Wood had telephoned Ledez's family to inform them of his intention to commit suicide.<ref name="30sep-86-guardian-1" /><ref name="talked down">{{cite news |title= Talked down |work= The Independent |date= 30 September 1986}}</ref>
==Legal proceedings== ===Extradition=== A day after Wood's surrender, British police filed an [[extradition]] request to French authorities to send Wood back to the UK for prosecution.<ref name="30-sept-86-ap-1">{{cite news|title=Attorney ordered jailed pending extradition request|work=The Associated Press|date=30 September 1986}}</ref> Wood decided not to object to the extradition request after a brief meeting with his family and was confident that he would receive a [[Right to a fair trial|fair trial]] in a British court.<ref name="29oct86-guardian-1">{{cite news |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260281296/ |title= Sheffield man Ian Wood appears before French court |work= The Guardian |via= Newspapers.com |subscription= yes |page=5 |date= 29 October 1986}}</ref><ref name="1-oct-86-guardian-1">{{cite news |url= https://www.newspapers.com/image/260271713/ |last= Page |first= Campbell |title= Wanted solicitor 'not to fight extradition' |via= Newspapers.com |subscription= yes |page=1 |work= The Guardian |date= 1 October 1986}}</ref> On 7 October, a formal request on behalf of the Director of Public Prosecutions was made to a magistrate in Sheffield.<ref name="7oct86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Warrant out |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503076952&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=3 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date=7 October 1986}}</ref><ref name="7oct86-indy-1">{{cite news |title= Warrant out for solicitor |work= The Independent |date=7 October 1986}}</ref><ref name="29oct86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor agrees to extradition |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503083482&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 29 October 1986}}</ref> Wood was flown back to the UK on 19 November where he was [[Remand (detention)|remanded]] in custody.<ref name="20nov86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor returned |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF501704428&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 20 November 1986 }}</ref><ref name="20nov86-guardian-1">{{cite news |title= Ian Wood faces murder charges |work= The Guardian |date= 20 November 1986}}</ref>
===Remand=== The police successfully applied to continue holding Wood on remand on double murder and attempted murder charges at [[Sheffield Old Town Hall|Sheffield Magistrates' Court]] on 22 November.<ref name="23nov86-st-1">{{cite news |title= Wood in court |work= The Sunday Times |date=23 November 1986}}</ref><ref name="22nov86-indy-1">{{cite news |title= Wood hearing |work= The Independent |date=22 November 1986 }}</ref><ref name="22nov86times-1">{{cite news |title= Lawyer remand |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503090231&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 22 November 1986}}</ref> Wood made a further short committal appearance in court on 1 December and his trial was formally announced on 3 February 1987.<ref name="4feb87-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor for trial |work= The Times |date=4 February 1987}}</ref><ref name="2dec86-times-1">{{cite news |title= Solicitor on murder charge |url= http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF501706905&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date=2 December 1986 }}</ref>
===Trial=== [[File:Sheffield OldTownHall east.jpg |thumb |Sheffield Old Town Hall, the venue for Wood's trial]]
====Pleas and charges==== On 1 December 1986, the prosecution charged Wood on two counts of murder and one count of attempted murder, for Danielle, Stephanie, and Christopher, respectively.<ref name="31jul87-indy-1" /> Wood also faced a [[specimen charge]] of stealing £84,000 from clients he represented in property deals,<ref name="9dec86-times-1">{{cite news|title=Solicitor's committal date is set |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503093896&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=7 |subscription= yes |date= 9 December 1986 |work= The Times}}</ref><ref name="5aug87-guardian-1">{{cite news|title=Victims of solicitor get 230,000 pounds|date=5 August 1987|work=The Guardian}}</ref> although the prosecution claimed the sum could have been £150,000.<ref name="23jul87-times-1"/><ref name="22jul87-times-1"/>
Wood pleaded not guilty to the murder of Danielle and instead entered a [[Manslaughter in English law|manslaughter]] plea on the grounds that they had agreed to a [[suicide pact]].<ref name="22jul87-times-1" /> The prosecution did not accept the manslaughter plea and pursued a trial for the murder of Danielle.<ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /> However, Wood pleaded guilty to the murder of Stephanie and the attempted murder of Christopher.<ref name="23jul87-indy-1" /> He also pleaded guilty to stealing [[pound sterling|£]]84,000 from clients.<ref name="23jul87-times-1"/><ref name="22jul87-times-1"/>
====Suicide pact claim==== The [[Homicide Act 1957]] states that if a person kills someone in pursuance of a suicide pact and then does not commit suicide themselves, they are guilty only of manslaughter and not murder.<ref name="homicideact-1">{{cite web|title=Homicide Act, 1957|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1957/11/pdfs/ukpga_19570011_en.pdf|website=www.legislation.gov.uk|publisher=Her Majesty's Stationery Office|accessdate=28 October 2017}}</ref><ref name="pact-manslaughter">{{cite news|last1=Rozenberg|first1=Joshua|title=When a suicide pact becomes a case of manslaughter|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/1481236/When-a-suicide-pact-becomes-a-case-of-manslaughter.html|accessdate=28 October 2017|work=The Telegraph|date=15 January 2005}}</ref> However, Geoffrey Rivlin, leading the prosecution, told the court that in such a situation the [[wikt:onus|onus]] is on the killer to prove that a suicide pact was made.<ref name="30jul87-times-1">{{cite news|title=Solicitor 'killed out of his obsessive hatred, not love' |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF500495138&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |last=Smith |first=Ian |page=3 |subscription=yes |work=The Times|date=30 July 1987}}</ref>
Wood gave the court a detailed account of the five-point agreement he claimed to have made with Ledez as to what to do after the killings and before his suicide:<ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /><ref name="31jul87-indy-1" /> #Visit a French church and light candles for Ledez and her children. #Send a detailed explanation of the deaths to the press. #Kill Ledez's husband, Colin Lloyd. #Ensure Ledez and her children were buried in a French village cemetery. #Visit their graves and lay flowers for them.
Rivlin argued that Wood's story did "not have a ring of truth about it".<ref name="22jul87-indy-1" /> Several of Ledez's French friends who were interviewed by police claimed that Ledez had shown no signs of depression or suicidal intentions. In addition, her mother received a telephone call hours before Ledez died and she did not suspect her daughter was suicidal.<ref name="23jul87-times-1" />
To support Wood's claim, the defence called Wood's mother, who said that Ledez had confided her suicidal intention to her on multiple occasions and that she feared that her husband Colin would physically harm her or Christopher.<ref name="28jul87-times-1" /> The witness also stated that Wood had called her within 24 hours of the shootings and explained the plan to her.<ref name="28jul87-indy">{{cite news|title=Solicitor's lover 'had threatened suicide 10 times'|work=The Independent|date=28 July 1987}}</ref> The prosecution called Alan Wales, Wood's doctor, who testified that he advised the police to confiscate Wood's gun collection after an appointment on 11 November 1985. Wales said that Wood appeared "distressed" and prescribed him with antidepressants.<ref name="28jul87-times-1">{{cite news|title=Mistress 'confided suicide intention' to Wood's mother|url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503113578&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |last=Smith |first=Ian |page=3 |subscription=yes |work=The Times|date=28 July 1987}}</ref>
On 30 July 1987, the final day of the trial, the prosecution argued that Wood's suicide threat on Amiens Cathedral was not genuine and was done only to disguise his true motive, with Rivlin summarising that Wood "killed out of his obsessive hatred, not love".<ref name="30jul87-times-1" /> Gilbert Gray, leading the defence, argued that Wood had nothing to gain from lying about a suicide pact because he would be sentenced to life imprisonment for the murder and attempted murder of Ledez's children anyway.<ref name="30jul87-times-1" />
====Verdict and sentencing==== On 31 July 1987, the jury at [[Sheffield Old Town Hall|Sheffield Crown Court]] unanimously rejected Wood's claim that he killed Ledez as part of a suicide pact and found him guilty of murder.<ref name="31jul87-indy-1" /> Justice Taylor sentenced Wood to life imprisonment for each murder, 12 years for the attempted murder, and three years for the specimen charges of theft from clients.<ref name="31jul87-indy-1" /> Wood was struck off the Law Society register and the [[Law Society Compensation Fund]] paid out at least £240,000 in compensation to the theft victims.<ref name="5aug87-guardian-1" /><ref name="guardian-online">{{cite news|last1=Dyer|first1=Clare|title=Murderer is kept on roll of solicitors|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2001/may/25/claredyer|accessdate=28 October 2017|work=The Guardian|date=25 May 2001}}</ref>
===Appeal=== On 28 August 1987, Wood's solicitor filed an appeal against the guilty verdict.<ref name="appeal lodged">{{cite news|title=Lawyer's plea against double life sentence |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF500496510&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=5 |subscription= yes |work=The Times|date=28 August 1987}}</ref> The appeal was rejected on 25 July 1989.<ref name="appeal denied">{{cite news|title=Solicitor loses appeal |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF500402025&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=4 |subscription= yes |work=The Times|date=25 July 1989}}</ref>
==Aftermath== ===Previous confiscations and police dispute=== After the trial, a dispute occurred between [[South Yorkshire Police]] and [[Sussex Police]] over which force was responsible for erroneously allowing Wood access to firearms.<ref name="1aug87-times-1">{{cite news|title=Police clash on gun blame|work=The Guardian|date=1 August 1987}}</ref> Wood's ten-piece gun collection had been confiscated twice; firstly in December 1985 over fears from his wife and doctor of deteriorating mental health and alcoholism, and secondly because of an administrative error in renewing his licence.<ref name="29sep86-times-1">{{cite news|title=Firearms given back |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF503074132&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=2 |subscription= yes |work=The Times|date=29 September 1986}}</ref> The guns were returned two weeks after the first confiscation.<ref name="29sep86-times-1" /> South Yorkshire Police later said that they had to return them because there was no evidence that Wood was a threat to himself or others.<ref name="31jul87-guardian-1" />
In March 1986, Wood bought 50 rounds of ammunition in Sheffield for his .38 Enfield revolver which he had inherited after his father used it to commit suicide.<ref name="31jul87-times-1">{{cite news|title=Errors gave killer his gun |url=http://find.galegroup.com/ttda/infomark.do?&source=gale&prodId=TTDA&userGroupName=somelib&tabID=T003&docPage=article&searchType=BasicSearchForm&docId=IF501722963&type=multipage&contentSet=LTO&version=1.0 |page=3 |subscription= yes |work= The Times |date= 31 July 1987}}</ref> South Yorkshire Police ascribed these events to an "administrative mix-up" with Sussex Police, who were responsible for executing the firearms clause in Wood's father's will.<ref name="1aug87-times-1" /> Sussex Police said that when Wood asked for the gun and the remaining 11 rounds they tried to dissuade him but he returned a month later with a renewed firearms certificate from South Yorkshire Police.<ref name="31jul87-times-1" /> The differing interpretations of the [[Firearms Act#United Kingdom|Firearms Act]] by the two police forces resulted in the [[Home Office]] intervening and seeking a detailed explanation from both forces and holding talks with them over possible amendments to the Firearms Act.<ref name="1aug87-times-1" />
===Firearms policy=== [[Bill Michie]], the [[Member of parliament#United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland|Member of Parliament]] for [[Sheffield Heeley (UK Parliament constituency)|Sheffield Heeley]], campaigned for stricter [[Firearms policy in the United Kingdom|firearm ownership]] regulations, such as [[psychiatric assessment]] of prospective gun owners, in response to the murders.<ref name="31jul87-guardian-1">{{cite news|title='Change gun law' call as lawyer is gaoled|work=The Guardian|date=31 July 1987}}</ref><ref name="guardian-09aug87-1">{{cite news|title=Changes sought in British gun law|work=The Guardian|date=9 August 1987}}</ref> In October 1986, Michie asked [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Prime Minister]] [[Margaret Thatcher]] if the government would change its firearms policy in response to the murders, to which she responded: "The Home Office ... will keep that matter under permanent review".<ref name="hansard-1">{{cite hansard|jurisdiction=United Kingdom|title=Engagements|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1986/oct/28/engagements#column_162|house=House of Commons|date=28 October 1986|column=162|speaker=|position=}}</ref>
Less than a month after Wood's conviction, the [[Hungerford massacre]] took place, in which Michael Robert Ryan killed 16 people. This prompted [[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] to pass the [[Firearms (Amendment) Act 1988]], which banned civilian ownership of nearly all [[Semi-automatic firearm|semi-automatic weapons]].<ref name="firearms-amendment-1">{{cite web |title= Firearms (Amendment) Act, 1997 |url= https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/1997/5/pdfs/ukpga_19970005_en.pdf |website= www.legislation.gov.uk |publisher= Her Majesty's Stationery Office |accessdate= 28 October 2017 }}</ref>

If you would like more information on how to add references to this article, please see http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Cite/Cite.php (Please format according to [[:Template:Cite web]], and [[Wikipedia:Citing sources]])--> {{coord|41.783457|-87.61219|display=title}}
[[File:Washington Park Subdivision map.gif|thumb|250px|Washington Park Subdivision is south of [[Washington Park, Chicago (park)|Washington Park]]. ([[Chicago Park District]] - green, [[University of Chicago]] - lavender)]] The '''Washington Park Subdivision''' is the name of the historic 3-[[city block]] by 8-city block subdivision in the northwest corner of the [[Woodlawn, Chicago|Woodlawn]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]], on the [[South Side (Chicago)|South Side]] of [[Chicago]] in [[Illinois]] that stands in the place of the original [[Washington Park, Chicago (race track)|Washington Park Race Track]]. The area evolved as a redevelopment of the land previously occupied by the racetrack. It was originally an exclusively white neighborhood that included residential housing, amusement parks, and [[beer garden]]s.
During the late 1920s and 1930s, the area became the subject of discriminatory twenty-year covenants, which were determined to be invalid by the [[United States Supreme Court]], when challenged in a seminal case brought by [[Carl Hansberry]]. The case is a vital part of legal studies and considered an important part of a broad class of histories. The play ''[[Raisin in the Sun]]'' is based on [[Lorraine Hansberry]]'s struggles in this neighborhood.
==Location== Due to the non-rectangular shape of the [[Washington Park, Chicago (neighborhood)|Washington Park]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]], the original [[Washington Park, Chicago (race track)|Washington Park Race Track]] actually occupied the Southern two-thirds of the Washington Park Subdivision, which is an 8-city block by 3-city block area in northwest corner of the [[Woodlawn, Chicago|Woodlawn]] community area and bounded by Dr. Martin Luther King Drive to the west, South Cottage Grove Avenue to the East, East 60th Street to the North and East 63rd Street to the South. This is the area directly south of [[Washington Park, Chicago (park)|Washington Park]] and both south and east of the Washington Park community area. It would be part of the Washington Park community area if the community area were to complete its logical proper rectangle.<ref name=WPS/>
==Historical significance== Between 1884 and 1905, the race track occupied part of the area now known as Washington Park Subdivision.<ref name=WPS/> After the city outlawed gambling, the area was redeveloped as a residential housing subdivision with neighboring commercial recreation such as the [[White City (Chicago)|White City amusement park]] that flourished until the [[Great Depression]].<ref name=WPS/> The neighborhood also included a beer garden that was remodeled by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]].<ref name=WPS/><ref name=W/>
Between 1900 and 1934, the [[African American]] population in Chicago grew from 30,000 to 236,000. In this time, [[Demographics of Chicago|Chicago's demographics]] changed so that instead of having this population diluted in scattered places, it was concentrated in two large strips of land. The concentration was enforced by violence at first, but restrictive covenants became the preferred way to enforce [[Racial segregation|segregation]] after a few decades.<ref name=THBHvL/>
When necessary, community organizations used violence to pursue their segregationist purposes, and between 1917 and 1921, bomb use discouraged encroachment into majority white neighborhoods. The bombs were used at the residences of African Americans as well as the properties of real estate agents and bankers.<ref name=PTI>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vPLEXRfnzJAC&pg=PA140&dq=%22Washington+Park+Court%22|title=Packing Them In: An Archaeology of Environmental Racism in Chicago, 1865–1954|chapter=Planning and Environmental Inequality|accessdate=January 3, 2009|year=2005|publisher=Lexington Books|author=Washington, Sylvia Hood|isbn=0-7391-1029-2}}</ref> In 1919, African American banking magnate [[Jesse Binga]], the owner of the first Chicago bank to be operated by African Americans, and the first African American who lived in the Washington Park Subdivision,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://negroartist.com/JESSE%20BINGA/index.html|title=Jesse Binga|accessdate=January 23, 2009|publisher=negroartist.com}}</ref> endured five bombings of his home by angry whites.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb1453/is_/ai_n29146315|title=Pinkster in Chicago: Bud Billiken and the Mayor of Bronzeville, 1930–1945|accessdate=January 1, 2009|journal=The Journal of African American History|author1=Rutkoff, Peter M. |author2=William B. Scott |lastauthoramp=yes |date=Fall 2004}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> Binga lived on the block diagonally northwest of the northwest boundary of the subdivision at 5922 South Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Drive.<ref>{{cite book|title=Not For Tourists Guide to Chicago|pages=74–75|isbn=0-9758664-9-4|year=2005|publisher=Not For Tourists Inc}}</ref>
Although they were previously rare, racially restrictive [[Covenant (law)|covenants]] among property owners that outlawed the purchase, lease, or occupation of their properties by African Americans became common in Chicago in the 1920s, following the [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]].<ref name=RC>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/1067.html|title=Restrictive Covenants|accessdate=December 31, 2008|year=2005|publisher=[[Chicago Historical Society]]|work=The Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago|author=Hirsch, Arnold R.}}</ref> Local businessmen and the [[University of Chicago]] became alarmed at the prospect of poorer African Americans moving from the Black Belt due to a combination of racial succession and economic decline.<ref name=W/> In 1926, the United States Supreme Court upheld racially restrictive covenants in Corrigan v. Buckley ({{ussc|271|323|1926}}).<ref name=THBHvL/> In 1927, the Chicago Real Estate Board (CREB) sent representatives throughout the city to promote such covenants, which it viewed as a progressive alternative to violence. The board representatives provided model contracts drafted by the [[Chicago Plan Commission]] as part of their efforts. By 1928, the ''[[Hyde Park Herald]]'' reported that the covenants prevailed throughout the [[South Side (Chicago)|South Side]],<ref name=RC/> and 95% of the homes in the subdivision were covenanted.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://archives.nd.edu/findaids/html/etext/alleycon.htm|title=An Alley in Chicago: The Ministry of a City Priest (paperback as An Alley in Chicago: The Life and Legacy of Monsignor John Egan)|chapter=Jack Was Starting Everybody's Fire|author=Frisbie, Margery|isbn=978-1-58051-121-6|publisher=Sheed & Ward|year=1991 (Paperback, 2002)}}</ref><ref name=BM>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=HR3d18hfm-8C&pg=PA184&lpg=PA184&dq=%22Washington+Park%22+subdivision+Chicago|title=Black Metropolis|author=[[St. Clair Drake|Drake, St. Clair]] and [[Horace R. Cayton, Jr.|Horace Roscoe Cayton]]|pages=184|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|isbn=978-0-226-16234-8|year=1993}}</ref> Most African American neighborhoods were bounded by covenanted areas since 85% of Chicago was covenanted.<ref name=THBHvL/>
==Legal issues== Between 1928 and 1940, the subdivision was a legal battleground. In 1928, [[landlords]] in the subdivision signed the covenants in which they agreed that they would not rent to non-whites. The language of the covenants state that no properties in the subdivision "...shall be sold, given, conveyed or leased to any negro or negroes, and no permission or license to use or occupy any part thereof shall be given to any negro except house servants or janitors or chauffeurs employed thereon..."<ref name=RRCotWPSitCoC>{{cite web|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/covenant.html|title=Racial Restrictive Covenant of the Washington Park Subdivision in the City of Chicago|accessdate=January 1, 2009|date=September 1, 2003|publisher=[[Arizona State University]]|author=Plotkin, Wendy |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070210063636/http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/covenant.html |archivedate = February 10, 2007}}</ref> The covenants were signed by "owners of land on the one or the other side of Evans, Langley, Champlain, St. Lawrence, Rhodes, Eberhart, Vernon and South Park Avenues, between 60th and 63rd Streets and on 60th, 61st and 62nd Streets between South Park and Cottage Grove Avenues" on September 30, 1927, and they were recorded at the Cook County Register of Deeds on February 1, 1928. They were intended to be valid and in force until January 1, 1948.<ref name=RRCotWPSitCoC/>
The [[Great Depression]] decreased white demand for the subdivision's properties. A few well-off African Americans convinced some owners to sell properties to them. The most famous case was that of Dr. James L. Hall, who rented a property located at 419 E. 60th St. from the white Issac Kleiman.<ref name="Chicago Defender">{{cite web|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/gentzel.html|title=Judge Gentzel Upholds Jim Crow Plot; To Appeal Woodlawn Property Owners Show Colors in Tilt Against Race|work=Chicago Defender|author=staff|date=August 5, 1933|accessdate=January 2, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070210063446/http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/gentzel.html |archivedate = February 10, 2007}}</ref> In 1933, Olive Ida Burke (the wife of Mr. Burke—a future defendant in the famous [[Hansberry v. Lee]] case)<ref name=THBHvL/> sued Kleiman in the case now known as ''Burke v. Kleiman''.<ref name=THBHvL/> The circuit court granted an injunction in favor of the plaintiffs, which was upheld on appeal by the [[Supreme Court of Illinois]].<ref name=Burke>{{cite web|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/burke.html|title=Burke v. Kleiman Decree (Partial), August 3, 1933|accessdate=January 2, 2009|publisher=Wendy Plotkin |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070210063056/http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/burke.html |archivedate = February 10, 2007}}</ref> The plaintiffs stipulated that as of 1928 more than 95% of the property owners signed the covenant. This stipulation was later proved false—only 54% had actually signed.<ref name=THBHvL/>
In 1937, Carl Hansberry purchased a property from James Joseph Burke located at 6140 South Rhodes. Anna M. Lee, and other promoters of the covenants, sued to prevent Hansberry's family from living in the neighborhood.<ref name=injunction>{{cite web|url=http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/cc.html|title=State of Illinois — County of Cook In the Circuit Court of Cook County Anna M. Lee, et al. vs. Paul A. Hansberry,et al. Gen. No. 37C 6804 Complaint in Equity Complaint to Enforce Restrictive Agreement Injunction and Other Relief|publisher=Wendy Plotkin|accessdate=January 2, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070210062826/http://www.public.asu.edu/~wplotkin/DeedsWeb/cc.html |archivedate = February 10, 2007}}</ref> This led to the [[Hansberry v. Lee]], {{ussc|311|32|1940}} case. Defendants argued that the stipulation made previously in Burke v. Kleiman that more than 95% of the owners had signed the covenant was false and the case should be reajudicated.<ref name=THBHvL/> Plaintiffs, while admitting to the fact, contended that the principle of ''[[res judicata]]'' barred courts from rehearing the old arguments.<ref name=THBHvL/> The Illinois courts ruled in favor of plaintiffs. However the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] decided to represent the buyer in the [[United States Supreme Court]]. The case caught the attention of national real estate magazines and African American newspapers.<ref name=BM/> The [[U. S. Supreme Court]] eventually reversed that ruling stating the application of ''res judicata'' in this case would violate [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]].<ref name=THBHvL/> The play ''[[Raisin in the Sun]]'' was inspired by [[Lorraine Hansberry]]'s time in the neighborhood after her father won the repeal of restrictive covenants.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/programs/morning/features/patc/raisin/|title=A Raisin in the Sun |accessdate=February 16, 2009|date=March 11, 2002|publisher=[[NPR]].org}}</ref>
The result of ''Hansberry v. Lee'' led to racial succession. White tenants were often [[eviction|evicted]] to make way for higher-paying African American renters.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=px0PuO7GWhsC&pg=PA44&lpg=PA44&dq=%22Washington+Park%22+subdivision+Chicago|title=Making the Second Ghetto: Race and Housing in Chicago 1940–1960|chapter=The Second Ghetto and the dynamics of neighborhood change|author=Hirsch, Arnold R.|authorlink=Arnold R. Hirsch|isbn=978-0-226-34244-3|publisher=[[University of Chicago Press]]|year=1998}}</ref> By 1950, the subdivision was over 99 percent African American.<ref name=WPS>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/1320.html|title=Washington Park Subdivision|accessdate=December 31, 2008|year=2005|publisher=[[Chicago Historical Society]]|work=The Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago|author=Seligman, Amanda}}</ref><ref name=W>{{cite web|url=http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/1378.html|title=Woodlawn|accessdate=December 31, 2008|year=2005|publisher=[[Chicago Historical Society]]|work=The Electronic Encyclopedia of Chicago|author=Seligman, Amanda}}</ref> The Hansberry case is a seminal case in [[civil procedure]] and [[class action]] legal studies.<ref name=THBHvL>{{cite journal|url=http://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/Vol20/Issue3/DavisVol20No3_Kamp.pdf|title=The History Behind Hansberry v. Lee|accessdate=January 2, 2009|publisher=University of California, Davis|work=UC Davis Law Review|volume=20|pages=481–500|author=Kamp, Allen R.|year=1986–1987|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612184930/http://lawreview.law.ucdavis.edu/issues/Vol20/Issue3/DavisVol20No3_Kamp.pdf|archivedate=June 12, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref> It is also considered an important study of African American, [[History of Chicago|Chicago]] and [[legal history]].<ref name=THBHvL/>
While the purchase case proceeded, some landlords subdivided properties and rented them to blacks at a premium. Some realtors began encouraging white families to move out so that they could rent properties to African Americans. Smaller property owners were pressed to sell to realtors or directly to African Americans because the neighborhood was undergoing a racial transformation.<ref name=BM/> The conditions of this neighborhood are described in a section of ''[[Black Metropolis]]'' by [[St. Clair Drake]] and [[Horace R. Cayton, Jr.|Horace Roscoe Cayton]].<ref name=BM/>
The Supreme Court ruling and several similar rulings led to the racial transformation of the [[Woodlawn, Chicago|Woodlawn]] and [[Hyde Park, Chicago|Hyde Park]] [[Community areas of Chicago|community area]]s. Political futures were determined by positions taken on this issue. Future five-term [[Mayor of Chicago]] [[Richard J. Daley]] ran for Cook County Sheriff in 1946 as a progressive anti-covenant candidate.<ref name=RC/> Eventually, in [[Shelley v. Kraemer]], {{ussc|334|1|1948}}, which was argued by [[Thurgood Marshall]], the U. S. Supreme Court declared restrictive covenants in general unenforceable.<ref name=RC/>
